content:
re :. I have removed the account from Thunderbird, as well as all the related contacts,

Oauth request access can occur for mail account email and gmail contact address book and also gmail calendars.

You say you have completely removed the gmail mail account. So it's no longer in Thunderbird. You mention removing all related contacts - however contacts are just email addresses which can be move to any address book.....can I assume you have also removed all gmail address books ?

Have you removed all gmail calendars that were related to the account?

Have you removed saved passwords for that gmail account?

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Scroll down to 'Passwords' section
  • Click on 'Saved Passwords'

If you see any lines that mention gmail and the email address of 'removed' gmail account, then select the relevant lines(s) and click on 'Remove'. Click on 'Close'

Exit/Close Thunderbird and wait a few moments for background processes to complete and then start Thunderbird.

content: try port 587 and STARTTLS
creator: davidsk

content: Didn't work...connection timed out and didn't send. Put it back to Port 465 and SS/TLS and wonder of wonders, it sent. This is very confusing. Sometimes it will send and sometimes not.
creator: tommymeisel

content:
I would suggest trying normal password not oauth. While it does appear in the database for comcast I have a strong suspicion that is is only available for comcast corporate email accounts not customer accounts and it has somehow ended up in the general database for all.

Historically connections were encrypted using SSL. This protocol was fundamentally superseded some 10 years ago by TLS which performs exactly the same function in end to end encrypted connections. Thunderbird still uses the terminology SSL/TLS although the SSL part of the encryption was turned of years ago. Selecting SSL/TLS in Thunderbird is selecting TLS

Outgoing Mail Server Name: smtp.comcast.net Port Number: 587 (SMTP) If Needed: 465 (SMTPS)

These are both provided on the Comcast website in that form, however the accepted standard is to use SMTPS when using encrypted connections i.e. SSL/TLS. So choose port 465.

Encryption: TLS (use SSL if TLS isn't shown.) See https://www.xfinity.com/support/articles/email-client-programs-with-xfinity-email

This discussion from 2019 indicated Xfinity made a change some 6 years ago requiring encrypted connections, so my guess is the oAuth authentication method is not working for you, not the other settings. But check them just to be sure. https://www.xfinity.com/support/articles/update-your-xfinity-email-settings
creator: MattAuSupport

content: I changed the authentication to normal password, still on port 465. I am able to send mail now, but for the past few days it would stop sending and I would get a message from the server that there has been "excessive failed authentication, ESMTP server temporarily not available." Comcast tech support was a waste of time. My email works fine if I use their website, and they say that means the problem is on my end. My Outlook had the same problem, which is why I downloaded Thunderbird. This is all very confusing to this old man! Thanks for your response, I appreciate it! Tommy Meisel
creator: tommymeisel

content:
do you have an antivirus scanning outgoing mail. Disable that function and see ho it goes. If you have a VPN make sure Thunderbird is exempted from the VPN when connecting to the server. Many US based internet service providers require you to connect to the internet from their network to send mail, (no such requirement to get mail),and a VPN by design actually hides that so they refuse connections.

Check the outgoing server (SMTP) entry in the account settings list of accounts and ensure if you have more than one Comcast outgoing server that the settings for all of them are correct. It is easy to click reply on a mail and have a different outgoing server for that identity selected.

Finally access the Thunderbird password manager and remove all SMTP passwords stored there for Comcast so you can be sure everything is fresh.

It is a support cop out from your ISP that if they are able to keep their website up that any issues you have with mail protocols is your problem. Their stuff is working. That is akin to telling you you have electricity so any issues with your phone are your end. Vaguely related as both use electricity but that is about where it ends. Likewise email protocols for mail clients use different servers and ports to those used by their webmail offering. Both are internet based and that is about where the similarities end.

content:
Hello there

In the time that you send me that crash report. Try to start up in troubleshooting mode. Go for that sending these same mails and these same attachments to a test e-mail address that is added on the pc to test if that issue is still there when that pc is in trouble shoot mode. It can be useful to start with safe modus for win or Mac then after that run Thunderbird into that troubleshoot mode. That one installed add on can be turned off in the meanwhile. Look for the antivirus software on that pc , and scan moments that are running for thunderbird at the same time or not with the Thunderbird software , turn these scans temporarily to off.
creator: Googlethunderbird.

content:
Hello there

Windows 10 home edition. It can be that all the other causes for crashing is related to that Window 10 edition home. It could be that this version that is recently on that running pc is outdated or either being corrupted. You might consider to replace that operating system or to update and check for all subjects that are interrupting that normal behavior of it.

If these symptoms still occur after these actions, I would recommend you to check the surrounding software for the same as described above.

Or create a new profile at thunderbird if these problems persist. A tip : Try disabling Windows Search Indexing. Disabling indexing the download folder may cause change.

If Thunderbird is still crashing when the files need to be attached in that email consider to check that antivirus or add on. To remove temporary these softwares the change to a better thunderbird environment can be there. Try to start up in that same method of getting into that safe mode option for that operating system and then try to get into that Thunderbird troubleshoot mode to investigate the recent problem. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/troubleshoot-mode-thunderbird

Be sure that all programs are updated Even on that pc itself (Drivers and a lot of other programs that are similar to these drivers can be replaced or updated for a moment. )..

https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/releases/

If there ain’t a security program on that pc yet , try to get one online there are many trail versions to find on google like window defender clean and try to clean that pc with a cleaning tool if possible.



Questions are open


Greetings googlethunderbird.
creator: Googlethunderbird.

content:
Thanks all.

I closed the app and reopened the app. It didn't help. Today, I closed the app and didn't reopen the app until a few hours later. Then the sync occurred.

This is quite odd. It seems the sync isn't working correctly in various ways.


Notes: 1. In all these actions, the folders have at least 7k mails. I wonder if this matters (seeing new folder with large# of emails/removing folder with large number of emails).

Thunderbird should at least show new folder names (if not able to add all mails into a new folder right away) according to the configured sync intervals. This way, at least I know Thunderbird is detecting a change.

I wonder if Thunderbird is stuck trying to perform one big task (e.g. trying to add 8k mails to one single folder) and never gets to add all new folder names first.

Perhaps Thunderbird should tackle the sync w top-level tasks first (e.g. add/remove folder names), then do the add/remove mails incrementally for each folder (if such tasks are taking too long to complete).

    • I'd think Thunderbird would want to at least fix the app's sync so I don't have to collapse/reopen the email account's top level tab or close/re-open the app to get sync working.

2. The max mail/folder size it synced still bothers me. This means I can't keep the #of mails in any folder > 8k mails.

3. Syncing is quite fast in Outlook Classic. I wonder the reason syncing is slower in Thunderbird vs. Outlook Classic?
creator: honwaim

content:
Thunderbird doesn't have a max size.

I'd say something is throttling you. Also, in support circles yahoo's behavior is known to erratic.
creator: wsmwk

content:
If you sent from the MyName account but the recipient replied to the Info account, it means the MyName account was sending through the smtp with Info's User Name, and gmail automatically made your message appear to be sent from Info.

You must have separate smtp servers for each account, with the same settings except for the User Name, and set each account to send through the matchong smtp:

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1350593
